content: The "Veterans' Benefits Act of 2011" includes a pilot program to assess claims-processing skills. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to assess and provide training for employees responsible for processing claims for compensation and pension benefits. This program includes biennial skills assessments and individualized training for employees and managers of the Veterans Benefits Administration. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to assess and provide training for employees processing claims for benefits. Training will be individualized based on assessment results, with remediation provided for any deficiencies in skills. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program at five regional offices of the Veterans Benefits Administration. Employees or managers who do not pass the assessment after two remediation attempts will face appropriate personnel actions. $5,000,000 is authorized for this program. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will allocate $5,000,000 for a pilot program from 2012 to 2016. Reports on assessments, training, and personnel actions will be submitted annually to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will allocate $5,000,000 for a pilot program from 2012 to 2016, with reports on assessments, training, and personnel actions submitted annually to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. EXCLUSION OF CERTAIN REIMBURSEMENTS OF EXPENSES FROM DETERMINATION OF ANNUAL INCOME WITH RESPECT TO PENSIONS FOR VETERANS AND SURVIVING SPOUSES AND CHILDREN OF VETERANS. The amendment to section 1503(a)(5) of title 38, United States Code, excludes reimbursements for expenses related to accidents from being counted towards annual income for veterans and their families. The exclusion under section 1503(a)(5) of title 38, United States Code, includes the fair market value or reasonable replacement value of equipment or vehicle involved in an accident, theft, or loss. The exclusion under section 1503(a)(5) of title 38, United States Code, includes medical expenses resulting from accident, theft, loss, or casualty loss, with a limit on the amount excluded based on the costs incurred. The amendment limits the exclusion of medical expenses related to accident, theft, loss, or casualty loss, including pain and suffering, with a cap set by the Secretary. The effective date of the amendment is one year after enactment. Additionally, the authority to obtain information from the Department of Treasury is extended until 2013. Authorization of electronic communication for notifying claimants for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The amendment to Section 5103 of title 38, United States Code allows the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to provide information to claimants through electronic communication or in writing, without the need for redundant notices for subsequent claims filed while a previous claim is pending. The amendment to Section 5103 of title 38, United States Code allows the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to provide information to claimants for subsequent claims filed within one year, as long as the evidence supports the maximum benefit. This does not eliminate any requirements for notice contents under regulations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to assist claimants in obtaining private records. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is mandated to assist claimants in obtaining private records by making reasonable efforts to obtain relevant records. If unable to obtain all records, the Secretary must notify the claimant, identify the missing records, explain the efforts made to obtain them, and proceed with the claim based on available evidence. The Secretary must make at least two requests to obtain relevant private records, unless the first request shows a second would be futile. The section does not apply if the evidence allows for the maximum benefit to be awarded based on the record. The term 'maximum benefit' refers to the highest evaluation supported by the evidence at the time of the decision. The Secretary is required to follow regulations for obtaining private records. Under regulations, the Secretary encourages claimants to submit relevant private medical records if it does not burden them. The Secretary may require authorization to obtain private records to comply with laws. Assistance for disability compensation claims includes obtaining service medical records. The Secretary encourages claimants to submit relevant private medical records. The Secretary may require authorization to obtain private records. Assistance for disability compensation claims includes obtaining service medical records from governmental entities, Department health-care facilities, and other Federal departments or agencies upon claimant's identification and authorization. Efforts to obtain records from Federal departments or agencies shall continue until obtained. Efforts to obtain records from Federal departments or agencies shall continue until obtained, unless it is reasonably certain that such records do not exist or further efforts would be futile. SEC. 6. CONDITIONS FOR TREATMENT OF CERTAIN PERSONS AS ADJUDICATED MENTALLY INCOMPETENT FOR CERTAIN PURPOSES. Section 5511 of title 38, United States Code, states that a person must be deemed mentally incompetent by a judicial authority to be considered a mental defective for certain purposes under section 922 of title 18. SEC. 7. REINSTATEMENT OF PENALTIES FOR CHARGING VETERANS UNAUTHORIZED FEES. Section 5905 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include penalties for soliciting fees related to filing claims for benefits under the laws administered by the Secretary. The amendment to Section 5905 of title 38, United States Code, includes penalties for soliciting fees related to filing claims for benefits under the laws administered by the Secretary. Any act that attempts to obtain a benefit or claim, commits an offense, aids in the commission of an offense, or causes an act that would be punishable by law, will result in fines, imprisonment, or both. The amendment applies to acts committed after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 8. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is limited to paying $2,000,000 in performance awards annually for fiscal years 2012 through 2016 under section 5384 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 9. The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined by reference to the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010.
